conclusion: Two particles, A and B, are placed on the same horizontal plane and start moving in a straight line simultaneously from rest, from the same position, and in the same direction.
The v-t (velocity-time) graph of their motion is shown in the figure.
Analysis of the motion of A and B: what is the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for A and B during their deceleration phases?
Particle A: after reaching the peak speed 2v₀ at t = t₀ it decelerates linearly to zero speed at t = 3t₀.
Particle B: after reaching speed v₀ at t = 4t₀ it decelerates linearly to zero speed at t = 6t₀.
Acceleration (or deceleration) magnitude = change in speed / time taken for that change.

premise: Δv = 2v₀ → 0 gives Δv = 2v₀ and Δt = 3t₀ – t₀ = 2t₀
Δv = v₀ → 0 gives Δv = v₀ and Δt = 6t₀ – 4t₀ = 2t₀
The magnitude of particle A’s deceleration is twice that of particle B; the ratio is 2 : 1.
conclusion: The ratio of the accelerations of A and B during deceleration is 1:1.
